column2: John Wesley, the founder of Methodism, described his preaching for the first time outside the confines of the pulpit as â€œsubmitting to be more vileâ€. Hitherto he had seen this as something alien to his understanding of his mission. That was my feeling when, at the start of a year as lord mayor of Bradford in 2016, I was expected to use Twitter on a daily basis. Apparently it was a 21st-century civic tradition and it was expected of me. The only way I could cope with this alien activity was by reflecting on the dayâ€™s activities for up to half an hour and carefully crafting a suitable sentence arising out of one event, a harmless ritual that some people appreciated. Marina Hydeâ€™s assertion that arguing on the internet qualifies you as a twat is perfectly sound (What better owner for Twitter than Elon Musk, master of the ill-advised tweet?, 26 April). Apart from that, he wouldnâ€™t emit so many tonnes of CO2 shooting cars stupidly into space, and he wouldnâ€™t distract us all from our common fate on Earth with his fairytales (presumably also proprietary) about the future on Mars and beyond. If thereâ€™s to be any kind of â€œradical transitionâ€ that offers us all a future, it has absolutely nothing to do with Musk and his ilk.Alastair PennyDurbuy, Belgium  Joel Golby suggests that the best thing Elon Musk can do is delete Twitter (27 April). Heâ€™s not going to do that. However, those who are concerned about a self-promoting billionaire controlling online discourse have a simple solution: delete your own Twitter account. I know that these online platforms have a way of becoming addictive and users feel that they cannot live without their â€œdrug of choiceâ€ â€“ but really, we lived for thousands of years without Twitter. Anything that was so popular with Donald Trump must be suspect â€“ and if enough people just delete their accounts, it will die. That would be worthwhile and really funny: to see Musk so spectacularly â€œburnedâ€.Martin CoultLondon  Have an opinion on anything youâ€™ve read in the Guardian today? column2: A group representing domestic football leagues is hopeful of killing plans to make Champions League places dependent on historic performance, believing they will find â€œcommon groundâ€ with Uefa to stop the controversial proposal. The European Leagues, which represents domestic competitions from across the continent including the Premier League, said that they believed their support for qualification on â€œsporting meritâ€ and a lower number of fixtures in a still expanded Champions League would result in a â€œwise and goodâ€ decision by Uefa president Aleksander Ceferin. Speaking on Friday, however, the president of the European Leagues, Claus Thomsen, reiterated a commitment to the principle of qualifying based on domestic performance. â€œWe believe the principle of sporting merit is the heart of the football model,â€ he said. â€œItâ€™s still our firm belief and position that such a thing canâ€™t be introduced into the European club competitions. â€œWe have had good dialogue with Uefa on this and think we will find common ground with this. With a league format set to replace the group stage, the number of guaranteed fixtures played by each qualifier would rise from six to 10 per season, creating a further 100 matches in the competition. column2: Neil Parish, the Conservative MP for Tiverton and Honiton, has reported himself to the parliamentary authorities over allegations that he watched pornography in the House of Commons chamber. Rumours about the identity of the MP had been rife in Westminster since it emerged earlier this week that a female Conservative minister had reported seeing a colleague watching pornography on his phone in the Commons â€“ an account corroborated by another MP. A spokesperson for the chief whip, Chris Heaton-Harris, said Parish was reporting himself to the Standards committee of the House of Commons over the allegations. â€œMr Parish has been suspended from the Conservative whip pending the outcome of that investigation,â€ the spokesperson said. Boris Johnson had encouraged witnesses to report the individualâ€™s behaviour to the independent complaints and grievance scheme, which polices MPsâ€™ behaviour; but was facing pressure to take more immediate action. Parish has held the safe Conservative seat of Tiverton and Honiton, in Devon, since 2010, winning it with a huge majority of 24,239 in 2019. He is the chair of the Defra select committee, known at Westminster as a champion for animals and farming, quizzing MPs in recent Commons appearances about fertiliser prices and greyhound racing. Before Parishâ€™s name emerged, several Conservative MPs, including Nickie Aiken and Simon Hoare, had called on the unnamed MP accused of watching pornography to resign, rather than risk others being wrongly named. Parish gave an interview with GB News earlier this week, in which he was asked about allegations of a Conservative MP watching pornography. â€œI think the whipsâ€™ office will do a thorough investigation and we will wait and see that result and from that, then the decision will have to be made what action will be taken,â€ he said. Pressed on whether there was a problem with the culture at Westminster, Parish said, â€œWeâ€™ve got some 650 members of parliament in what is a very intense area. You are going to get people who step over the line.â€ He added: â€œIt does have to be dealt with and dealt with seriously.â€

Once nicknamed Britainâ€™s favourite German â€“ the 54-year-old once joked he was â€œtop of a short listâ€ â€“ the six-time grand slam winner was worth about Â£38m in his heyday in prize money and sponsorship deals. Even after he retired, Beckerâ€™s good humour and colourful private life kept him in the publicâ€™s eye and affection, despite a previous conviction for tax evasion and attempted tax evasion in Germany in 2002. column2: Dear old Doctor Who has been in the doldrums. The pesky pandemic caused production delays, panicked rewrites and truncated series. Ratings have slumped, buzz has been badly lacking, and critical kickings have been administered. But all is not lost for the BBC franchise. Apart from the imminent return of showrunner Russell T Davies, thereâ€™s another ray of light â€“ and it comes in the form of a transgender-led podcast. Written by Juno Dawson, Doctor Who: Redacted was launched alongside the Easter TV special, Legend of the Sea Devils, and has been described by the producer/director Ella Watts as â€œvery gay, very transâ€, and sitting â€œto the leftâ€ of the main show. The 10-part BBC Sounds audio drama follows three best mates who make â€œthe Blue Box Filesâ€, a paranormal conspiracy podcast about a certain police box popping up throughout history. Their tongue-in-cheek theorising suddenly gets all too real when theyâ€™re sucked into an action-packed alien adventure of their own. The cat is FINALLY out of the bag: I produced and directed a very gay, very trans OFFICIAL @BBCDoctorWho fiction podcast by @junodawson, starring @Charlie_Craggs, @iamrahh and @LoisChimimba and it comes out next sunday! #DoctorWhoRedacted ğŸ³ï¸â€âš§ï¸ğŸ³ï¸â€ğŸŒˆhttps://t.co/awuJnethPn pic.twitter.com/7fFIg4XIoE The friends are university dropouts, who now live in different UK cities but stay connected via their hobby podcast. The leader of the gang (and the drama) is a trans woman, Cleo, who works as a theatre usher, lives on a south London estate and is saving up for surgery. Sheâ€™s played by transgender activist Charlie Craggs, a scene-stealer in her first ever acting role, who describes her casting as â€œa huge step for the trans community. Iâ€™m so honoured to be part of something so sacred to so manyâ€. Juno Dawson always had Craggs in mind to play her protagonist. â€œSheâ€™s such a force,â€ says Dawson. â€œThe label â€œtrans activistâ€ can be a club with which to beat trans people. Itâ€™s a dehumanising term, but Charlie uses her voice so cleverly â€“ with humour and honesty. When it came to casting, I said to Ella: â€˜Look, we can either audition Charlie Craggs or find a trans actor and tell her to play it like Charlie Craggs.â€™ There were some nerves at the BBC about hiring someone untrained but Iâ€™m so glad we stuck to our guns.â€ Founder of the podcast-within-a-podcast is devoted â€œboxspotterâ€ and resident believer Abby (Vigilâ€™s Lois Chimimba), who is bisexual and a full-time carer for her sick mother in Glasgow. The lineup is completed by sceptical Shawna (Grange Hillâ€™s Holly Quin-Ankrah), an out-and-proud lesbian studying computing at her local college in Sheffield. Interestingly, this regional diversity is what came first for Dawson. â€œBeing from Bradford myself, I adore hearing regional accents on the BBC,â€ she says. â€œI love that Doctor Who has lived its life in Cardiff, Sheffield and Liverpool in recent years. That regionality isnâ€™t there enough in BBC drama, which is often kind of placeless. So, before I even thought about their gender or sexual identity, it was important to me that they were from different parts of the UK. Shawna was specified in the script as being a black or mixed-race woman from the north, whereas Abby was always going to be from Glasgow, which is one of my favourite cities.â€ â€œThe three loser-teersâ€, as they self-deprecatingly style themselves, discover that everyone who has ever met the Doctor is disappearing, their very existence being forgotten. Theyâ€™re being â€œredacted from realityâ€. Is there an allegorical significance here? â€œSomewhat,â€ says Dawson. â€œThe notion of being silenced or erased feels part of the online language nowadays. But, I would say to the listener: itâ€™s Doctor Who, donâ€™t read too much into it. Itâ€™s more about a threat hanging over the world.â€ Ironically, the Blue Box Files is so unsuccessful that our heroines are the last names on the hitlist, making Cleo, Abby and Shawna the worldâ€™s only hope. They must race against time to uncover the truth and avert â€œend-of-the-world-type dangerâ€. As the drama unfolds, they are joined by familiar faces â€“ OK, voices â€“ most notably, the 13th Doctor herself (Jodie Whittaker). Also reprising their Doctor Who spin-off roles are Rani Chandra (Anjli Mohindra) of The Sarah Jane Adventures, and UNITâ€™s Kate Stewart (Jemma Redgrave), Petronella Osgood (Ingrid Oliver) and Madame Vastra (Doon Mackichan). As well as the Time Lordâ€™s allies, certain well-known monsters make an appearance too. â€œIt was such a thrill to play with these beloved characters,â€ says Dawson. â€œItâ€™s like borrowing someone elseâ€™s toy box. As long as you give the toys back in mint condition, you can just go mad. I was in the next room as Jodie was recording my dialogue, and admit I cried. I never cry! I never thought in a million years Iâ€™d get to see the Doctor reading dialogue Iâ€™d written for them.â€ ğŸ™ï¸ The TARDIS visits @BBCSounds for Doctor Who: Redacted.Produced by @BBCStudios, @BBCDoctorWho spin-off podcast scripted by @JunoDawson will feature Jodie Whittaker and introduce stars @Charlie_Craggs, @LoisChimimba & Holly Quin-Ankrah.https://t.co/ZNvnFTAByK But the podcast is not just peppered with cameos, it also nods to Who storylines past and present. Tardis companions Martha, Ryan, Graham and Yaz get name-checked. So do previous TV plot details such as the dodgy dieting company Adipose Industries and that time an entire hospital got teleported to the moon by talking space rhinos. Not that Dawson wanted the podcast to be all about pleasing the purists. â€œI didnâ€™t want it to be too heavy on fan service,â€ she says. â€œThe reason Doctor Whoâ€™s been running for nearly 60 years is because itâ€™s always kept the door open to new fans. Especially with each new Doctor, thereâ€™s an invitation to come in and join the party. But there are Easter eggs and little callbacks. The girls have a podcast investigating the legend of the Doctor, so it makes sense theyâ€™d be hunting for clues. At the same time, it tells its own story. You donâ€™t need to have seen a lot of Doctor Who to understand Redacted.â€ The high-stakes narrative is cleverly interwoven with the trioâ€™s personal lives. Abby might have a controlling boyfriend (â€œthe man-babyâ€) lurking in the background but she and Shawna have a sweet will-they-wonâ€™t-they romantic subplot. Despite class clown Cleo insisting sheâ€™s â€œonly here for the sass, babeâ€, we learn that her mother kicked her out when she started to transition in her teens, but is now seriously ill and trying to reconcile. â€œItâ€™s hard not to feel for Cleoâ€™s character,â€ Craggs has said. â€œYouâ€™d have to be some sort of sociopath not to empathise with what sheâ€™s going through with her mum.â€ Dawson agrees: â€œI wanted to highlight that Cleoâ€™s had a difficult old life but, like Charlie, has developed a thick skin to hide her pain. Thatâ€™s something that Russell T Davies did particularly well. If you make the humansâ€™ lives feel real and layered, then, somehow, the sci-fi feels more real as well. Thereâ€™s something delicious about seeing a Yeti on the tube or a Dalek going over Tower Bridge. Itâ€™s the extraordinary mixed with the ordinary. I wanted the characters to feel like your nextdoor neighbours.â€ She scripted four of the 10 episodes herself, with the rest credited to new writers â€“ again, with a strong emphasis on diversity and regionality. With Redacted, bestselling author Dawson becomes the Doctor Who franchiseâ€™s first openly trans lead writer. For a lifelong Whovian who calls the show her â€œfirst loveâ€, thatâ€™s a big deal. â€œWhen I watched Bonnie Langford [who played companion Mel] as a kid, I decided I wanted to be her,â€ she says. â€œAnd then Sophie Aldred came along as Ace, an even stronger character who killed Daleks with a baseball bat. Long before I knew I was a girl, I knew I was Mel and Ace. The show had a huge impact on me, so itâ€™s a privilege to put my own little flag on the landscape.â€ Whittaker has enthused about working with Dawson and Craggs, saying â€œtheir energy is aceâ€. Redacted is, indeed, irresistibly sparky. Characters are powered by protein shakes and oat milk lattes. Episodes run to a pacy 20 minutes. The dark conspiracy plot is leavened by a script that zings with Drag Race lingo and gags about alien penises in jars. Harry Styles is hailed as â€œan honorary lesbianâ€. â€œLive, laugh, loveâ€ culture and boomers who leave voicemails are roundly ridiculed. Itâ€™s like a sci-fi remix of Mae Martinâ€™s Feel Good. Or Itâ€™s A Sin with aliens also saying â€œLa!â€. As such, itâ€™s going down a storm. â€œI was nervous because the fandom are so passionate,â€ says Dawson. â€œIâ€™ve been that judgmental fan myself. But people have been incredibly positive. That goes for the queer and trans community too. A lot of the messages that Iâ€™m getting online are from people saying, â€˜I feel seenâ€™.â€ Doctor Who has long flirted with gay subtext. Since its 2005 reboot, queer characters include Captain Jack Harkness (John Barrowman) and Madame Vastraâ€™s wife, Jenny Flint, but it wasnâ€™t until five years ago that the franchise introduced its first full-time LGBTQ+ companion, Bill Potts (played by Pearl Mackie). She was swiftly followed by Whittaker as the Doctorâ€™s first female incarnation â€“ recently revealing her feelings for companion Yaz (Mandip Gill). The show received an Ally award at the 2017 PinkNews Awards for its â€œlong-standing LGBT inclusivenessâ€. Now that Redactedâ€™s cast and crew of diverse queer women are saving the universe, itâ€™s another step forward for representation. â€œDoctor Who has always appealed to LGBTQ+ people,â€ says Dawson. â€œThereâ€™s something so enduring about the idea that, if youâ€™re living a slightly humdrum life, this person in a blue box can whisk you away for an adventure in time and space. Many of the Doctorâ€™s sidekicks have been downtrodden or marginalised, even if they werenâ€™t outwardly queer. So to take that subtext and make it text, that means a lot. We donâ€™t need to make it a metaphor any more. We can have three queer women front and centre.â€ Doctor Who: Redacted is available on BBC Sounds, with new episodes each Sunday.
column4: â€˜Very gay, very transâ€™: the incredible Doctor Who spin-off thatâ€™s breathing new life into the franchise

column2: You can sort of tell what kind of film writer-director-co-star Savvas D Michael thought he was making, given the lofty references to Homerâ€™s Iliad in the plotting, Martin Scorsese movies in the dialogue, and Guy Ritchie in the casting â€“ given the presence here of Vinnie Jones in a cameo role. But Platoâ€™s home life is only peripheral to the story, which mostly revolves around the exploits and hijinks of him and his crew, a motley selection of knaves, one of whom is a supposedly handsome and supposedly unbeatable scrapper named Achilles (played by Michael himself). Stung when his romantic overtures are rejected by local beauty-cum-poker-hustler Lola (Lois Brabin-Platt, whose display of sass represents one of the filmâ€™s few amusements), Achilles goes into a sulk in Homeric fashion. This causes considerable distress in particular to Achillesâ€™ No 1 fan, Anthony (Jamie Crew), seemingly also expected to be considered an object of pity given Crewâ€™s manic and mannered display of verbal diarrhoea, delivered with a speech impediment and jerky movements. Perhaps Anthony is the character for whom weâ€™re supposed to feel sorry. That said, hardly anyone is even vaguely likable here, which neednâ€™t necessarily have been a drawback, but they should at least be in some way interesting. No such luck. Londoners may find amusement in trying to guess where the exteriors were shot.  The Bezonians is on digital platforms from 2 May.
